claim: Books included in the ban in Ireland are Catcher in the Rye, Brave New World, and Ulysses.

supporting.text: The Irish Censorship of Publications Board historically banned 'Ulysses' by James Joyce in 1929 due to its perceived obscenity.

attacks.text: The Irish Censorship of Publications Board historically banned 'Ulysses' by James Joyce in 1929 due to its perceived obscenity.
The ban on 'Ulysses' was lifted in 1936, so it is not accurate to say it is currently banned in Ireland.
While the ban was lifted, the initial ban still supports the claim that 'Ulysses' was historically included in Ireland's censorship efforts.
The claim mentions multiple books, but 'Catcher in the Rye' and 'Brave New World' were not banned by the Irish Censorship of Publications Board.
The claim may refer to broader cultural or institutional bans beyond the Irish Censorship of Publications Board.

supporting.text: 'Brave New World' by Aldous Huxley was not banned in Ireland, as there is no record of it being formally censored by Irish authorities.

attacks.text: 'Brave New World' by Aldous Huxley was not banned in Ireland, as there is no record of it being formally censored by Irish authorities.
Historical records indicate that 'Brave New World' was informally suppressed in Ireland through social and cultural pressures, even if not officially banned.
The absence of formal censorship records does not necessarily mean the book was freely available, as informal suppression can be just as effective.
Irish authorities did not include 'Brave New World' in any official list of banned books, which is well-documented.
Official lists may not capture all instances of suppression, as some bans were enforced through indirect means.

supporting.text: 'The Catcher in the Rye' by J.D. Salinger was not subject to a ban in Ireland, as no official censorship records support this claim.

attacks.text: 'The Catcher in the Rye' by J.D. Salinger was not subject to a ban in Ireland, as no official censorship records support this claim.
While no official records exist, anecdotal evidence suggests that 'The Catcher in the Rye' faced informal restrictions in some Irish institutions.
Informal restrictions do not constitute an official ban, and without documented evidence, they cannot be equated to state censorship.
Some Irish literary scholars argue that the absence of official records does not necessarily mean the book was never restricted, as censorship practices were inconsistent.
Historical research on Irish censorship confirms that all banned books were documented, making unrecorded bans highly unlikely.

supporting.text: The claim is partially true for 'Ulysses' but false for 'Brave New World' and 'The Catcher in the Rye', as only 'Ulysses' faced an Irish ban.

attacks.text: The claim is partially true for 'Ulysses' but false for 'Brave New World' and 'The Catcher in the Rye', as only 'Ulysses' faced an Irish ban.
Historical records show that 'The Catcher in the Rye' was indeed banned in Ireland in the 1950s due to its perceived obscenity.
While 'The Catcher in the Rye' was banned in Ireland, 'Brave New World' was never formally banned there, supporting A4's claim about it.
'Brave New World' was restricted in Ireland under censorship laws, effectively making it banned for certain audiences.
The restriction on 'Brave New World' was not a full ban and was later lifted, unlike the formal ban on 'Ulysses'.
